awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: Collaborative Research: Rankine-Hugoniot Conditions Relating the Gyrotropic Regions of Collisionless Shocks in Non-Thermal Plasma
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop a new and more accurate model of shock waves in rarefied plasmas in space and laboratory environments.  So-called collisionless shock waves belong to the most fundamental phenomena occurring in hot and rarified plasmas. Astrophysical waves accelerate particles, dissipate energy, and strongly perturb the environment they propagate through by converting dynamic pressure of a plasma flow into thermal energy.  One of the central theoretical issues in modern plasma physics is a quantitative prediction of the plasma state behind a shock wave (downstream) for given parameters in front of it (upstream). The majority of directly observed collisionless shocks are in the heliosphere; however, they can also be created in a laboratory.  The grand challenge of this project is to develop a new theoretical approach that would, on the one hand, account for the details of how individual particles interact with shock waves in collisionless plasma, but on the other hand, identify easy-to-use relationships between upstream and downstream conditions, similar to those widely used for shock waves in aerodynamics.  The project will train students and postdocs in computational science and plasma physics, as well as expose them to international science cooperation via collaboration with Ben Gurion University supported by the U.S. - Israel Binational Science Foundation.

Collisionless shocks (CSs) are ubiquitous in many space physics, astrophysics, and laboratory settings.  Despite more than six decades of CS research, the present status of the problem remains essentially unchanged in comparison to the early advances.  Application of standard Rankine–Hugoniot conditions to CSs is either invalid or highly inaccurate.  The objective of this research is to incorporate the essential ion dynamics at shock fronts into a statistical description which would make it possible, on the one hand, to avoid going into details of ion motion and, on the other hand, abandon ad hoc assumptions related to the equations of state.  Local hybrid and fully-kinetic PIC simulations will be used to validate and improve on the probabilistic, test-particle approach. This research will ensure a substantial step forward in the CS physics by providing a theory which can be compared quantitatively with real observations. The probabilistic approach is expected to be efficient for other problems of plasma physics, where the full kinetic approach is currently impossible, while the assumptions based on the fluid approximation are not valid. Its relative simplicity and ability to cover a wide range of shock parameters makes it possible to create convenient analytic formulae and/or lookup tables to be used by a wide range of plasma physicists. These will also be useful for the development of global magnetohydrodynamic models involving collisionless shocks enabling, in particular, more accurate forecasting of space weather.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Shocks are some of the most fascinating and important phenomena in space and astrophysical plasmas. For example, a standing shock in front of the Earth, called the bow shock, decelerates and heats the solar wind, a stream of plasma coming towards the Earth from the Sun. Thus, the Earth’s bow shock plays an important role in mediating the interaction between the solar wind and the Earth’s magnetosphere. Shocks can also form in the interplanetary space, for example because of solar eruptions. Arrival of such shocks can trigger geomagnetic storms and other significant space weather events at Earth. Understanding of shocks is thus crucial to understanding of space weather.  In more distant astrophysical objects, shocks are thought to be the dominant source of cosmic rays and play an important role in star formation. On smaller scales, for example in laboratory plasmas, shocks are essential to modern efforts to harness the power of nuclear fusion. While shocks differ significantly between the system discussed above, they also share many common properties, stimulating significant efforts to understand the basic physics of shocks in hot, magnetized plasmas. One of the major efforts is to relate conditions in front and behind the shock. This is important in many practical situations, including for modeling shock propagation, understanding space weather effects of the shocks, and particle acceleration by the shocks.   In typical space and astrophysical plasmas, this task requires sophisticated, self-consistent simulations taking into account the dynamics of individual particles in the shock and their interaction with shock-induced electromagnetic field. Such simulations are highly challenging to perform and thus cannot be used in global models (e.g., space weather models or global models of the heliosphere).  The major objective of the proposed research was to investigate dynamics of energetic ions at shocks using a methodology that is intermediate between fully consistent kinetic simulations and analytical descriptions, in part with the aim to develop methods for understanding effects of the shocks that could be used in global models.

 

The major activities and outcomes of the project are: 1) jump conditions valid in the immediate vicinity of the shock transition have been developed taking into account presence of energetic ions (pickup ions, in particular) and heavy ions (alpha particles); 2) A probabilistic description of the jump conditions applicable, additionally, to time-dependent and non-planar shocks has been developed, based on results of numerical tracing of particles through model shocks; 3) Analytical calculations and test particle simulations have been supported and verified by fully-self consistent modeling based on the hybrid and fully-kinetic, particle-in-cell approaches; 4) A set of jump conditions linking immediate vicinity of the shock and regions further downstream from the shock has been derived. In combination with the jump conditions linking upstream and immediate downstream region, the new expressions link upstream to isotropic regions downstream of the shock; 5) A large parameter scan using hybrid simulations has been performed to study the relaxation downstream from the shock and to tabulate the jump conditions; 6) Influence of shock structure and shock non-stationarity  on ion transmission through the shock has been analyzed. 7) The developed theory and modeling results have been compared against available in situ shock observations at New Horizons, Ulysses, MMS, and Voyager spacecraft.

 

The project is an international collaboration between groups at the University of Alabama, Huntsville, Space Science Institute, and Ben-Gurion University in Israel. Members of the project team participated in several international research collaborations and co-organized mini conferences at APS DPP meeting on plasma physics. Two postdoctoral scholars participated in the work performed at Space Science Institute, gaining invaluable expertise and training in modern high-performance computing and plasma theory. Several other postdocs and students were involved at the partner institutions. The results have been broadly disseminated via multiple publications and conference presentations.
